pages.text: Fallacosteus turneri was a genus of camuropiscid arthrodire placoderm that lived during the Late Devonian (around 382.7 - 372.2 million years ago). Its fossils have been found at the famous Gogo Formation of Kimberly, Western Australia. Like its close relative Camuropiscis, Fallacosteus had a flattened,

elongated snout that was likely used to improve its streamlining during swimming. And speaking of Camuropiscis, Fallacosteus's name translates to "deceptive bone", a reference to just how deceptively similar it looks to its relative.
